articles.title: Pregnancy Health and Wellness
articles.title1: Mindfulness During Pregnancy and Early Motherhood:
articles.description1: It’s impossible to overlook the physical changes of pregnancy. But, as dramatic as those changes may be, the invisible transformations you experience en route to motherhood are every bit as far-reaching.
articles.title2: Awakening the Senses: Pregnancy Body Changes:
articles.desciption2: How your senses are affected by the hormonal changes of pregnancy.
articles.title3: Pregnant With Possibility, Bursting with Life:
articles.description3: Your body knows exactly what it needs to do to prepare itself for pregnancy, birth, and beyond.
articles.description4: Pregnancy is not supposed to be a nine-and-a-half-month ticket to the buffet — nor is it supposed to be a nine-and-a-half-month exercise in self-denial.
articles.description6: Belly-button soreness, skin tags, dry eye? Yep, they're all pregnancy-related.

articles.title: Pregnancy Worries
articles.description1: Here's what you need to know about the top ten first-trimester worries that are most likely to have you pacing the floor at 3 a.m
articles.desciption2: How to worry less during the middle trimester of pregnancy.
articles.description3: Reassuring words about your third-trimester worries.
articles.description4: Healthy ways to manage stress during pregnancy.
articles.title5: Older Women More Likely to Perceive Pregnancies as High Risk:
articles.description5: Older moms, including those who are experiencing low-risk pregnancies, are more likely to feel that their babies are at risk.
articles.title6: Fetal Movement Counting Reduces Maternal Anxiety:
articles.description6: Pregnant women who monitor their babies’ movements via fetal movement counting during the third trimester tend to be less anxious about their babies’ wellbeing than other pregnant women.

articles.title: Perinatal Mood Disorders
articles.title1: Breaking the Silence on Prenatal Depression:
articles.description1: Mothers should be screened for the warning signs of depression long before delivery day.
articles.title2: Depression: A Risk Factor for Preterm Birth:
articles.desciption2: A recent study published in the medical journal Human Reproduction found that depressed pregnant women are twice as likely to give birth prematurely as pregnant women without any symptoms of depression.
articles.title3: TLC Show I Didn't Know I Was Pregnant Taps Into Fear of Childbirth:
articles.description3: Reality TV shows like I Didn't Know I was Pregnant exist because our culture has so much fear of childbirth.
articles.title4: The Best and Worst Video Moments: Pregnancy and Babies:
articles.description4: The camera has always been fascinated with babies. Just think of the rolls and rolls of photos your parents took of you (assuming, of course, that you were lucky enough to be a first-born child).
articles.title5: 12 Myths About Predicting Your Baby's Sex:
articles.description5: Since the beginning of time, expectant parents have tried to guess whether the baby they are carrying is a boy or a girl. Here's the scoop on seven of the most prevalent myths about predicting your baby's sex.
articles.title6: Pregnant Women, Babies, and the Flu Shot:
articles.description6: Here's what you need to know to protect yourself and your baby from influenza, an illness that can lead to serious complications, including pneumonia.
